ul.li: Your Strength score becomes 23 if it is lower.
You have advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks.
Once per turn, on your turn, you can expend 10 feet of movement to leap up to 30 feet.
Your Unarmed Strikes can deal bludgeoning damage equal to 1d8 + your Strength modifier on a hit.
You can attack twice, instead of once, when you take the Attack action on your turn. You ignore this benefit if you already have a feature, like Extra Attack, that gives you extra attacks.

element.name: Draconic Soul
element.supports: Bard, Druid, Ranger, Sorcerer, Warlock, Wizard, Spell Saving Throw

description.p: You invoke the power of dragons, becoming wreathed in elemental energy. Choose one damage type from among acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison. You are immune to that damage type for the duration. In addition, until the spell ends, you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: You gain a fly speed equal to your walking speed, and you can hover.
If you are not wearing heavy armour, your AC equals 13 + your Dexterity modifier (shields’ benefits apply as normal).

When you take the Attack action, you can replace one attack with an exhalation of draconic energy in a 30-foot cone. Creatures in that area must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw, taking 4d10 damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success. The damage type you deal is the same as the type you choose when you cast this spell.
You have blindsight out to 10 feet.

description.p: At higher levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the damage dealt by your draconic exhalation increases by 1d10 for each slot level above 4th.

You weave a spell of magical taxation over a creature you can see within 90 feet. The target makes an Intelligence saving throw, taking 3d10 psychic damage on a failed save or half as much on a success. A creature who fails the save is also cursed for the duration of this spell. While cursed, any time it casts a spell using a spell slot while you are within 90 feet of it, it takes a further 1d10 psychic damage, and you regain one spent spell slot of your choice of a level up to half of the level of the spell slot they expended (rounded down).

setters.set: a scroll of indecipherable, magical legalese

element.name: Creeping Exhaustion
element.supports: Bard, Sorcerer, Warlock, Wizard, Spell Saving Throw

description.p: Undulating tendrils of smoke spiral from your outstretched palm towards a creature you can see within 60 feet. The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be wracked with a curse of lethargy. For the duration, a cursed creature must choose whether it moves, takes an action, or takes a bonus action on each of its turns; it can only perform one of the three without penalty. If the creature performs more than one of the three on a single turn, it takes a point of exhaustion for each one beyond the first. When this spell ends, any levels of exhaustion it caused go away as the curse lifts.

You attempt to subtly subvert the flow of time in your immediate area. At the end of initiative count 0 of this round, if you are concentrating on this spell, the spell ends and initiative order is reversed (creatures with lower initiative act before those with higher). This new initiative order continues for the rest of the encounter.

setters.set: a pocket watch worth at least 100 gp

element.name: Pillar of Salt
element.supports: Cleric, Druid, Wizard, Spell Saving Throw

description.p: When you cast this spell, you target a creature within 60 feet and magically forbid an Action or behaviour. For example, you might forbid the Attack action, Dodge action, the Magic action, or a behaviour such as telling a lie or donning a shield. The creature magically understands the forbidden Action or behaviour, even if it does not speak your language.

For the duration of the spell, if the target willingly performs the forbidden Action or behaviour under their own power, they must make a Constitution saving throw. On a successful save, they take 20d12 force damage. On a failed save, they are turned into a pillar of salt, dying instantly. A creature killed in this way can only be resurrected by the Wish spell.

The creature is exempt from punishment if the declared behaviour is necessary to prevent it from immediate harm. For example, a creature ordered not to move can move without penalty to avoid being crushed.

You place two fingers to the temple of a willing creature that is concentrating on a spell and fortify its mind with magical resilience. For the next minute, that creature has advantage on concentration checks made to maintain concentration on that spell. This spell ends early if that creature loses concentration.

A weapon or piece of ammunition you touch becomes blessed with dancing enchantment magic, infusing it with golden light and aiding it striking true. The next attack roll made with that weapon or piece of ammunition deals an additional 3d8 force damage on a hit, and scores a critical hit on a 19 or 20. After it has been used to make an attack, the weapon or ammunition returns to normal and this spell ends.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the force damage increases by 2d8 for each slot level above 1st.

element.name: Wall of Necrosis
element.supports: Cleric, Sorcerer, Warlock, Spell Saving Throw

description.p: You create a wall of shadow and corrosive necrotic energy on a solid surface within range. You can make the wall up to 60 feet long, 20 feet high, and 5 feet thick, or a circle up to 20 feet in diameter, 20 feet high, and 5 feet thick. The wall is pitch black, opaque, and lasts for the duration. Creatures and objects can move through the wall; it is composed entirely of magical energy. Creatures are blinded while within the wall.

Each creature within the wall when it appears, or who enters the wall for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 5d12 necrotic damage and its speed falls to 0 until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, a creature talks half as much damage and its speed isn’t reduced.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d12 for each slot level above 5th.

You conjure an ordinary, non-magical, theater ballistic missile. If you conjure it on the ground, it detonates immediately. If you conjure it in the air, it emits a piercing whistle and falls at a rate of 500 feet per round, detonating upon contact with the ground or another surface.

When the missile detonates, each creature and object in a 60-foot-radius sphere centered on the point of detonation takes 20d12 bludgeoning damage. Creatures within 250 feet of the detonation that can see it must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, they are bpnded and deafened until the end of their next turn.
You babble a string of numbers at a creature within 30 feet of you that can hear you.
Start a 30 second timer.

Roll 1d4 and record the result. Roll a number of d4s equal to that result. Add those d4s together, and multiply that result by your Intelpgence modifier. Then subtract from this total the number you initially rolled on the d4, plus a number equal to the number of feet the target is away from you divided by 5. The target takes psychic damage equal to the final result.

If the timer runs out before you complete the calculations for this spell, or you perform the calculations with the aid of another person or digital tool, you take 1d6 psychic damage, the spell fails, and you do not expend the spell slot used to attempt its casting.
You interrupt a creature in the process of casting counterspell. This spell cannot be countered by counterspell.

setters.set: 1 reaction, which you take when you see a creature within 60 feet of you casting counterspell

element.name: Dice Tower
element.supports: Bard, Cleric, Druid, Sorcerer, Warlock, Wizard

description.p: Start a 30 second timer.
You have until the timer runs out to stack 1d4, 1d6, 1d8, 1d10, 1d12, and 1d20 on top of each other, in any order. The dice must start unstacked.

If the timer goes off with every dice stacked, unsupported by anything other than each other and the surface they are stacked on, you regain all your hit points. If you are charmed, frightened, paralyzed, or stunned, the condition ends. If you are prone, you can use your reaction to stand up.

When you make a melee weapon attack roll and miss, you can use a reaction to give yourself +5 to all melee weapon attack rolls you make against the target of that attack until the start of your next turn. This bonus applies to the triggering attack, potentially turning a miss into a hit.

setters.set: 1 reaction, which you take when you miss a creature with a melee weapon attack roll

description.p: You magically encourage the triggering creature and turn its momentary support into a distraction for another creature. The triggering creature can reroll the d20 and use the higher roll.

You can then choose a different creature you can see within range (you can choose yourself). The chosen creature has disadvantage on the next attack roll or ability check it makes within 1 minute. A creature can be disempowered by only one use of this spell at a time.

setters.set: 1 reaction, which you take when a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself fails on an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw

element.name: Mr. Stark, I Don’t Feel So Goodberry

description.p: One berry appears in your hand, infused with deadly magic. It appears identical to an ordinary goodberry. A creature can use its action to eat the berry. Alternatively, you can attempt a melee attack roll using the berry (with which you are proficient) against an unwilling creature no more than one size larger than you to force the berry into its mouth, causing it to swallow it (this attack deals no damage). A creature that swallows the berry takes 10d6+40 force damage. If this damage reduces the target to 0 hit points, it is disintegrated.
Start a 1 hour timer.

Name a word. For the duration of this spell, anytime a player says that word, they lose one hit point. If the GM says the word, one creature currently under their control loses one hit point (if possible).
Conjure one ordinary fly in a space you can see within range. It does not obey your commands.
